clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Pressure Muscle Index to Avoid Over-assistance During Pressure Support Ventilation
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Pressure Muscle Index to Avoid Over-assistance During Pressure Support Ventilation

brief_summary.textblock: Pressure support ventilation (PSV) is the most commonly used mode in mechanical ventilated patients. Studies have shown that over-assistance was prevalent in patients undergoing PSV. Up to now, no reliable method has been recommended to select an "optimal" inspiratory support level. Pressure muscle index (PMI) was introduced recently to evaluate the degree of spontaneous breathing effort. We hypothesize that PMI might be used as an indicator for over-assistance during PSV. In this randomized crossover study, inspiratory support is set at three levels according to negative, positive and zero PMI. Inspiratory effort, work of breathing, and respiratory mechanics are compared among the three inspiratory pressure support levels.

primary_outcome.description: Inspiratory effort is measured as pressure generated by inspiratory muscles using esophageal pressure monitoring.
Work of breathing is measured by the Campbell diagram and pressure-time-product using esophageal pressure monitoring.

secondary_outcome.description: Respiratory system compliance is calculated as the ratio between tidal volume and driving pressure.

secondary_outcome.measure: Partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood (mmHg)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood
secondary_outcome.description: Partial pressure of oxygen in arterial blood is obtained by blood gas analysis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood (mmHg)
secondary_outcome.description: Partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial blood is obtained by blood gas analysis.
Respiratory rate calculation includes ineffective trigger.
Tidal volume is obtained by intergation of flow-time tracing.
Rapid shallow breathing index is calculated as the ratio between respiratory rate and tidal volume.

secondary_outcome.measure: The use of accessory respiratory muscle
secondary_outcome.description: The use of accessory respiratory muscle is observed at the bedside.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Mechanical ventilated patients within 48 hours after the transition from a controlled mode to PSV
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of neuromuscular disease
- History of diaphragm dysfunction and surgery
- History of esophageal, gastric or lung surgery
- Decreased level of consciousness
- Central respiratory drive dysfunction
- Considered withholding of life support
